content.description: Climb up the center of the boulder, then over to the right, following the cracks.
Climb up the center of the boulder then over to the left, following the cracks.

Start at the very left corner of the south face of the boulder. The climb starts out with a fun technical sequence to get past the roof, then finishes on the easy, but exposed slab. Try to stay right of the holds used for Roller Derby.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.

content.description: Climb just to the right of the north-west corner of the boulder, above the large crack used for Bum Steer.
content.protection: Bouldering Pad. Descend down the western side of the boulder stemming against the tree.
content.location: Located on the west side of the boulder (the side farthest from the road).

content.description: Start on the ground between Berlin Boulder and a largish rock to the north. Mostly rely on the crack towards the west end of the north face. There are some pockets and smaller holds. This is a good first climb on the boulder. The North side of the Boulder is easier than the south, but the sun can be glaring in the late morning.
content.protection: A crash pad and a spotter.

content.description:
Roller Derby is an easy slab climb on the backside of the boulder. Start with both hands on the low thin crack

and proceed upwards on the slab

without using the

large crack to the left.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a spotter.

content.description: Start low on the right side of the overhung south face in the obvious (and awesome) two part cavity. Move right and up the southeast arete to an easy top out. Raspberry Jam is a pure line with incredible movement, varied holds, and lots of fun. The route name is a little hint at the beta I used to get through the first few moves.Given the boulder's history, I'm fairly sure that this route has been done before, so feel free to comment, and I will adjust the name and grade accordingly. It felt like V5 to me, but maybe there's an easier beta that I missed as well.
content.protection: Crashpads - 2 are sufficient, but the more the merrier.
content.location: It is on the right side of the overhanging south face and moves up the southeast arete.

content.description: Start on the edge rail and proceed upwards to some underclings and then some large jugs.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter, watch out for the large rock in the fall zone.
content.location: It ascends the center of the north face of the boulder.

content.description: Traverse under the roof on the overhanging south face, in either direction. There are some good holds, but some of the big moves are crazy.
content.protection: As it is near to the ground, little protection is needed. You may want a pad or a spotter for the area with the rock, though.
content.location: It is on the South side of the boulder.

content.description: Climb up the northwest corner of the boulder and to the left. A hidden jug makes it easier than you would expect.
content.protection: Boulder Pad and spotter. Descend down the western side of the boulder stemming against the tree.
content.location: On the north-west corner of the boulder.

content.description: Climb straight up near the right side of the boulder without using the arÃªte.
content.location: It is on the East face of the boulder.

content.description: Climb a slightly challenging start to an easy topout using the two ledges. Known as "Prowed of It" in the Boston Rocks guidebook.
content.protection: Climb is vertical and there are no large rocks underneath, so a crash pad should be all you'll need.
content.location: This ascends the northeast corner to the right of the obvious crack system.  Descend via Bum Steer on the opposite side of the boulder.

content.description: The crux is the deadpoint to the top hold.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location: Start slightly right to the middle of the cave, and go to the left and then up. The start holds are marked in green in the pic.

content.description:
This is the easiest route on the Berlin Boulder. Ascend the ramp-like crack then continue vertically right in front of the tree. 

  This is the path of descent for other climbs of the boulder.
content.protection: The tree makes it difficult to place a pad but also give you something to grab if you lose your grip
content.location: On the left side of the west face of the boulder (the farthest from the road).

content.description:
Located 20 yards from a gravel parking area, the Berlin Boulder is easily accessible. The boulder is well shaded even in colder months.

 Climbs are ordered starting at the Southeast corner and traveling around the boulder in a counterclockwise direction.
